title: The latest canvas for Refik Anadol’s AI-generated art? The new Sphere in Las Vegas
header: Refik Anadol’s AI data sculpture, “Machine Hallucinations: Sphere,” will debut Sept. 1 on the exterior of the futuristic Sphere venue in Las Vegas.

title: As California fires worsen, can AI come to the rescue?
header: Cal Fire is the first fire agency to use artificial intelligence to look for signs of wildfires and directly alert dispatch centers.

title: YouTube and Universal Music team up to experiment with AI
header: YouTube is partnering with Universal Music Group and singers such as Rosanne Cash to experiment with artificial intelligence in music production.

title: Column: What Stephen King — and nearly everyone else — gets wrong about AI and the Luddites
header: Is it foolish to believe that authors should resist having their works used to train AI without getting paid for it? Stephen King thinks so, but he misunderstands some important history.

title: Letters to the Editor: Ban AI-generated ‘deepfakes.’ The risk to society is extreme
header: Social media influencer Caryn Marjorie may find her AI-generated clone helpful, but what happens when we can no longer tell real scientists and leaders from frauds?

title: You’re not hallucinating: A massive, AI-generated glowing cube lands in Beverly Hills
header: The Gagosian art gallery in Beverly Hills has opened a large-scale installation of moving advertisements attempting to reflect the “state of our humanity.”

title: L.A.-Based Tech Company to Revealing Breakthrough Music AI Technology
header: Futureverse, a leading AI and metaverse technology and content company based in Los Angeles has announced the publication of research in the advancement of music AI with the launch of JEN 1, an unprecedented universal high-fidelity model for text-to-music generation.

title: Will AI replace writers — and the rest of us? An L.A. scholar-poet games out the future
header: Christopher Soto and USC poet and professor Jackie Wang have spent months talking about how AI will change writers’ livelihoods — and their art.

title: AI, self-tapes and weekends: Here are the stakes of the Hollywood strikes
header: Writers and actors on strike are forcing Hollywood to address deep-seated issues. The latest from the protests and what’s at stake on The Envelope podcast.

title: Video game voice actors say ‘soul of the industry is on trial’ with unregulated AI
header: As the actors’ strike continues, voice actors hope for their own contract requiring consent and compensation for AI to reproduce their voice or likeness.

title: Today’s Headlines: Poll finds widespread concern about AI
header: Plus: A coronavirus mystery, and California’s pork regulations are squeezing barbecue restaurants.

title: Column: These apps and websites use your data to train AI. You’re probably using one right now.
header: If you post images or words to a public-facing platform or website, chances are that information will be scraped by a system crawling the internet for AI firms.

title: LA Times Today: Inside the panic over AI music
header: When the song Heart on My Sleeve popped up on TikTok, the internet went wild. For the first time in years, Drake was collaborating with The Weeknd on new a track. The only problem was that neither artist was involved with the production of the viral hit. It was created using artificial intelligence.

title: As actors and writers push back on automation, Hollywood is in the midst of an AI hiring boom
header: Amid a pair of Hollywood strikes that have found screenwriters and actors questioning the rise of artificial intelligence, studios and streaming companies are bulking up on AI staff.

title: ‘Ed’ an AI chatbot will be LAUSD’s newest student advisor, Carvalho says in splashy show
header: Supt. Alberto Carvalho’s back-to-school speech at Disney Concert Hall took on the air of a Hollywood extravaganza.

title: Actors and writers aren’t the only ones worried about AI, new polling shows
header: Concerns about AI are central to the current Writers Guild and SAG-AFTRA strikes, but Americans in other industries also are worried, according to a new poll for the Los Angeles Times.

title: DannyLux, el romántico for the TikTok generation
header: In a genre long dominated by men sporting cowboy hats and five o’clock shadows, DannyLux offers fans a softer side to Mexican regional music.

title: When Harry met Sally’s AI
header: An influencer wants to be everyone’s AI “girlfriend.” And she’s found a way to upcharge. Plus, box office bombs, including ‘Elemental’ and ‘The Flash,’ give Hollywood migraines.

title: What seven AI companies say they’ll do to safeguard their tech
header: Seven leading artificial intelligence firms announced new voluntary safeguards designed to minimize abuse of and bias within the emerging technology.

title: California attorney general investigating Tesla on Autopilot safety, false advertising
header: Tesla is under investigation by the California attorney general’s office due to complaints about the safety of its Autopilot program, according to a CNBC report.

title: Automated writing? Not so fast, says the Writers Guild of America
header: As AI is becoming more ubiquitous, the Writers Guild is proposing some guidelines for how to regulate it and avoid writers being cut out of the creation of TV and film.

title: Can a chatbot preach a good sermon? Hundreds attend church service generated by ChatGPT to find out
header: Hundreds of German Protestants attended a church service in Bavaria that was generated almost entirely by artificial intelligence.

title: 11 more crash deaths are linked to automated-tech vehicles
header: Eleven more people were killed in crashes involving vehicles using automated driving systems during a four-month period this year, according to newly released government data.

title: Opinion:  I’m co-teaching my college class with ChatGPT. Will it upstage me?
header: After I present a new lesson, I’ll prompt ChatGPT to give a lecture on the same subject. My students will get a chance to see who does it better: the robot or the professor.

title: Los Angeles, 2043: An optimistic scenario for transportation
header: Los Angeles 2043: Imagine a metropolis where many people have forsaken cars in favor of e-bikes, robo-taxis and public transit.

title: 9,000 authors rebuke AI companies, saying they exploited books as ‘food’ for chatbots
header: A letter signed by 9,000 authors calls out AI companies for allegedly using the writers’ books to train chatbots without consent, credit or compensation.

title: FTC probes ChatGPT over possible consumer harms
header: The Federal Trade Commission is investigating whether OpenAI’s conversational AI tool ChatGPT violates consumer protection laws.

title: Sarah Silverman and other bestselling authors sue Meta and OpenAI for copyright infringement
header: Sarah Silverman and several other authors have filed a lawsuit against Meta and OpenAI, the company behind ChatGPT, alleging copyright infringement.

title: Disasters like Hilary are a magnet for fraudsters. Look out for these scams
header: Online scammers are eager to tap into people’s need for aid as well as their desire to help. Be careful before you reveal sensitive personal information or open your wallet.

title: Column: Artificial intelligence chatbots are spreading fast, but hype about them is spreading faster
header: Will artificial intelligence make jobs obsolete and lead to humankind’s extinction? Not on your life

title: Bestselling authors Mona Awad and Paul Tremblay sue OpenAI over copyright infringement
header: Two bestselling novelists filed a suit against OpenAI, claiming the company used intellectual property to ‘train’ its artificial intelligence chatbot.

title: Lawyers who cited fake ChatGPT-provided cases in court are fined $5,000
header: A judge has imposed $5,000 fines on lawyers who used ChatGPT for research and wound up submitting fictitious precedents to support their case.

title: Comedians laugh off AI’s effect on stand-up: ‘Like eating processed foods’
header: Comics tend to skew skeptical that AI can replicate attributes including timing and presence. A general claim reigns that the best AI currently seems able to offer is lazy and outright basic joke-writing.

title: In San Francisco, Biden says AI has ‘enormous promise’ but comes with risks
header: The Biden administration aims to tackle the potential dangers of artificial intelligence, including misinformation, job losses, discrimination and privacy violations.

title: Lawyers blame ChatGPT for tricking them into citing bogus past cases in court
header: A judge is deciding whether to sanction two lawyers who blamed ChatGPT for tricking them into including fictitious legal research in a court filing.

title: With new legislation, Europe is leading the world in the push to regulate AI
header: Authorities worldwide are racing to rein in artificial intelligence, including in Europe, where groundbreaking legislation is being pushed through.

title: Letters to the Editor: Outsourcing human thinking to AI is a red line we shouldn’t cross
header: People gain and express insight from the process of writing. Outsourcing that to artificial intelligence for expediency puts our ability to think at risk.

title: 80% of C-Suiters Predict Positive Outlook on 2023 Revenues, Bolstered by Improving U.S. Economy
header: A March 2023 survey of 500 CFOs, C-suite executives, and managers from a variety of industries shows that, compared to last quarter, business leaders are more confident in the U.S. economy, with more than half of executives agreeing it will expand this year and have a positive effect on their 2023 Q2 revenues and beyond.

title: DNA scientists once halted their own apocalyptic research. Will AI researchers do the same?
header: Over four days in 1974, molecular geneticists hashed out a code of bioengineering ethics for the good of science and humans. Reining in AI will be a little more complicated.

title: Opinion: AI-assisted writing is close to becoming as standard as spell check. Here’s the catch
header: AI is on the verge of becoming a standard feature of word processing. The danger is that it will discourage us from thinking for ourselves.

title: Congress wants to regulate AI. Big Tech is eager to help
header: 123 companies, universities and trade associations spent $94 million lobbying the federal government on issues including AI in the first quarter of 2023 alone.

title: Microsoft to add Bing search to OpenAI’s ChatGPT in battle with Google
header: Microsoft plans to bring Bing search to ChatGPT. The software giant also plans to watermark the AI content it generates, so users know it’s not human-made.

title: Prominent AI leaders warn of ‘risk of extinction’ from new technology
header: Hundreds of business leaders and academic experts signed a brief statement from the Center for AI Safety, saying they sought to “voice concerns about some of advanced AI’s most severe risks.”

title: AI may be on its way to your doctor’s office, but it’s not ready to see patients
header: Giant corporations like Microsoft and Google, plus many startups, are eyeing healthcare profits from programs based on artificial intelligence.

title: Visionary Thought Leaders Discuss AI and the Legal Profession
header: During the In-House Counsel Awards presentation, attendees were treated to an expansive and fascinating conversation about one of the hottest topics affecting the legal world and beyond: the adoption and proliferation of AI in the commercial sphere.

title: Regulators take aim at AI to protect consumers and workers
header: Increasingly concerned about powerful AI systems, regulators say they’re directing resources toward identifying negative effects on consumers and workers.

title: China calls for stronger security measures to deal with risks from AI
header: China’s ruling Communist Party has warned of potential risks from advances in artificial intelligence and called for stronger security measures.

title: Elon Musk reveals new ‘X’ logo to replace Twitter’s blue bird
header: Elon Musk has unveiled a new ‘X’ logo to replace Twitter’s blue bird as he follows through with a major rebranding of the social media platform.

title: A new app aims to thwart AI plagiarism in schools, online media
header: The startup GPTZero, designed by a 22-year-old college student, has attracted 1.2 million registered users since January. It aims to deter the misuse of ChatGPT in classrooms.

title: ChatGPT’s creator warns Congress the technology could cause ‘significant harm’
header: ChatGPT’s creator and IBM’s privacy chief call for more regulation of AI technologies that are raising ethical, legal and national security concerns.

title: Forget Tesla. Mercedes is betting $45 billion it can become the king of luxury EVs
header: Mercedes-Benz Chief Executive Ola Källenius is putting his chips on rebuilding the electric-vehicle motor and outmaneuvering rivals on autonomous driving.

title: Dead Beatles, Fake Drake and robot songwriters: Inside the panic over AI music
header: AI won’t replace your favorite artist. But it will render obsolete some working musicians and songwriters. A nervous industry steels itself for more upheaval.

title: I asked ChatGPT to tell me where to eat for a week. Worst idea ever?
header: It was a short list that ignored a swath of cuisines and neighborhoods. No tacos, Chinese, Thai, Ethiopian, Vietnamese, Japanese or anything beyond sandwiches and fried chicken.

title: Elon Musk put new limits on tweets. Users and advertisers might go elsewhere
header: TikTok and Instagram users can scroll with abandon, but on Twitter users will face new limits capping the number of tweets they can view.

title: Opinion: AI isn’t magic. It’s just knowledge sausage
header: A common declaration about AI programs is that they’re learning abilities they weren’t trained to have. But that claim doesn’t quite hold up.

title: On the brink of a possible SAG-AFTRA strike, some actors are wary of AI. Here’s why.
header: Hollywood studios are showing growing interest in artificial intelligence, but the industry’s organized labor groups have qualms about automation.

title: LA Times Today: Afraid of AI? The startups selling it want you to be
header: Is artificial intelligence coming for your job? Anxieties surrounding A.I. are so high, the Biden administration weighed in with a blueprint for an A.I. bill of rights.

title: Column: Your boss wants AI to replace you. The writers’ strike shows how to fight back
header: Artists, journalists and screenwriters are leading the fight against employers who would seek to replace them with the products of ChatGPT and other generative AI software.

title: AI is Hollywood’s ‘Napster 2001 moment,’ entertainment lawyers warn
header: Actors fear artificial intelligence will replace them. Entertainment lawyers predict the future is more complicated than that.

title: ChatGPT opens door to four-day week, Nobel Prize winner says
header: The ChatGPT revolution opens the door to a four-day week by providing a major productivity boost for swathes of jobs, according to a Nobel Prize-wining labor economist.

title: $335,000 pay offered for ‘AI whisperer’ jobs in red-hot market
header: The jobs market is mushrooming for ‘prompt engineers,’ people who spend their day coaxing artificial intelligence systems to produce better results.

title: Column: Afraid of AI? The startups selling it want you to be
header: ChatGPT and other new AI services benefit from a science fiction-infused marketing frenzy unlike anything in recent memory. There’s more to fear here than killer robots.

title: Column: What it looks like when jobs disappear in the shadow of AI
header: Companies all over are laying off workers while experimenting with new AI-powered productivity tools. The connection is both obvious and maddeningly hard to pin down.

title: Thousands of Reddit communities go dark to protest new data fees
header: More than 6,000 Reddit communities are participating in a 48-hour blackout to protest new fees the company is imposing on third-party apps that use its data.

title: Opinion: An AI takeover is not inevitable — if we value creative work
header: The panic over products from OpenAI and other companies says more about our cultural moment than about the tech itself.

title: Column: The creators of ‘Mrs. Davis’ have a radical idea for AI: Shut it down
header: ‘Mrs. Davis,’ from ‘Lost’ creator Damon Lindelof and Tara Hernandez, asks: Do we want to live in a world where technology makes our decisions for us?

title: Opinion: An AI chatbot may be your next therapist. Will it actually help your mental health?
header: It will be tempting for insurers to offer up apps and chatbots to meet mental health parity requirements. But there’s little evidence that they help.

title: Real-time deepfakes are a dangerous new threat. How to protect yourself
header: In a frightening use of deepfake technology, scammers are using AI-powered audio and video to pass themselves off as their targets’ relatives or loved ones in real time.

title: Letters to the Editor: Using chatbots to write stunts cognitive growth. That isn’t good for society
header: The process of writing and rewriting your own work isn’t just about learning to communicate; it’s a fundamental part of human development.

title: Opinion: Worried that ChatGPT is coming for your job? An old assessment tool may have the answer
header: Bloom’s Taxonomy, a framework that describes levels of thinking, is a better tool for determining AI capabilities than comparing them with humans’.

title: Op-Comic: The next shooting spree? The GOP has an app for that!
header: ShotGPT, Whoogle? and SnapPray make it easy for Republicans in Congress to do nothing — or worse — on gun violence.

title: Is it real or made by AI? Europe wants a label for that as it fights disinformation
header: European Union pushes online platforms like Google and Meta to fight disinformation by adding labels to AI-generated text, photos and other content.

title: AI has striking writers freaked out. Can Hollywood avoid nightmare scenarios?
header: Hollywood’s AI panic. A producer dogged by fraud allegations. CNN’s Trump numbers.

title: Letters to the Editor: The writers’ strike isn’t just about AI — and AI threatens more than writers
header: Readers respond to growing concern that AI will replace writers and other creative workers.

title: Letters to the Editor: Where are mental health professionals in the development of therapy chatbots?
header: Readers debate the limits of AI chatbots to treat mental health conditions and the expertise required for these tools.

title: Opinion: Is it time to start considering personhood rights for AI chatbots?
header: ChatGPT, Bing Chat and other artificial intelligence breakthroughs raise tough questions about what we owe our digital helpers.

title: Amazon enters chatbot wars with AI startup partnership
header: Amazon Web Services will offer the startup’s products to its customers and run its next large language tool.

title: Dating in L.A. is exhausting, so I asked a chatbot to flirt for me. Things got weird fast
header: Snack’s new AI feature lets chatbots handle the initial getting-to-know-you conversations with potential suitors. It’s as strange as it sounds.

title: Microsoft brings Bing chatbot to phones after curbing quirks
header: Microsoft is taking its new Bing chatbot mainstream — less than a week after making major fixes to stop the AI search engine from going off the rails.

title: Letters to the Editor: Technology has a place in the classroom. Chatbots don’t
header: Teachers say that the process of writing is a fully human one that artificial intelligence resources like chatbots help circumvent.

title: Column: This artificial intelligence chatbot turns out to be a plagiarist — and an idiot
header: The tech site CNET brought in an artificial intelligence bot to write financial articles, but the product turned out to be worthless and even unethical.

title: Is ChatGPT a marvel or a farce? We interviewed the chatbot to find out
header: We interviewed ChatGPT, a chatbot that has garnered widespread attention for its ability to mimic human conversation. Then we brought in experts in artificial intelligence and the arts to analyze ChatGPT’s responses.

title: Op-Ed: Don’t ban chatbots in classrooms — use them to change how we teach
header: Banning ChatGPT is like prohibiting students from using Wikipedia or calculators. Even if it were the “right” thing to do in principle, it is impossible in practice.

title: LA Times Today: Thousands chatted with this AI ‘virtual girlfriend.’ Then things got even weirder
header: John Warnock wrote one of the shortest PhD dissertations in history, then changed the world of publishing and printing as co-founder of Adobe.

title: Thousands chatted with this AI ‘virtual girlfriend.’ Then things got even weirder
header: Caryn Marjorie, an influencer with 2 million followers on Snapchat, recently made a digital clone of herself. But what happens to social media creators when the robots come for their jobs?

title: Tom Hanks thinks people won’t care if AI  keeps him working in film forever
header: Tom Hanks knows artificial intelligence (AI) can have a deep-fake Tom Hanks appearing in film after he’s gone, but he’s not so sure people will care.

title: Do we want a future where humans are truly entertained by AI?
header: The strikes by actors and writers get at fundamental questions of what will entertain humans in the future, plus more from the week in Opinion.

title: Opinion: What Frankenstein, the Golem and Robo-Lincoln share with ChatGPT
header: We like to see life in the things we have created. We build them to walk. Then, seeing them walk, we believe they’re alive.

title: Column: Minimum wage ‘ghosts’ keep Google and Microsoft’s AI arms race from becoming a nightmare
header: Google and Microsoft think chatbots that can converse like humans are the future of web search. But the human workers who make sure they don’t screw up are treated as disposable.

title: The Importance of Ethical Values in an Increasingly Ethics-Challenged World
header: Amidst the passionate, oftentimes heated debate going on today around Artificial Intelligence-driven chatbots, one might be reminded of Robert Oppenheimer’s ominous quote referencing Hindu scripture, the Bhagavad-Gita.

title: Column: Publishers and media watchdogs are struggling with an onslaught of AI-written content
header: Would-be writers and artists think AI programs make it easy for them to seem smart and talented. They’re just sending editors more junk to throw away.

title: After Michigan shooting, one university used ChatGPT to offer help to students. It backfired
header: Vanderbilt University officials apologized for the email, saying that using the artificial intelligence chatbot to write the message was in ‘poor judgment.’

title: Mental health apps may put your privacy at risk. Here’s what to look for
header: A report by Mozilla notes that several apps aimed at mental health have improved their data privacy and security. But more than half still have problems, and some are terrible, Mozilla says.

title: Letters to the Editor: AI bots with personhood rights? Why we’re still far away from that
header: Real personhood requires the kind of emotional thinking that current artificial intelligence capabilities are nowhere near achieving.

title: Commentary: Bing and other AI programs are meant to behave like humans. Why are we shocked when they do?
header: Why are we surprised that Bing’s Sydney is getting pouty and that people are using ChatGPT to write stories for sci-fi magazines? We programmed AI to act human.

title: Google invests almost $400 million in ChatGPT rival Anthropic
header: Alphabet’s Google has invested almost $400 million in artificial intelligence startup Anthropic, which is testing a rival to OpenAI’s ChatGPT, according to a person familiar with the deal.

title: Column: I asked ChatGPT to write me a symphony, a letter to an ex and more
header: ChatGPT is the most sophisticated chatbot ever released. It’s making Google nervous, but I felt better after spending some quality time with it.

title: Apple unveils sleek, $3,500 Vision Pro goggles. Will they be what VR has been looking for?
header: Apple has unveiled a virtual reality headset that will test the company’s ability to popularize new devices after others failed to capture the public’s imagination.

title: Viral ChatGPT poses propaganda and hacking risks, researchers warn
header: Ever since OpenAI’s viral chatbot was unveiled late last year, detractors have lined up to flag potential misuse of ChatGPT by email scammers, bots, stalkers and hackers.

title: If you outsource one thing to ChatGPT, job-seekers say this should be it
header: Cover letters are notoriously hard to write. These job seekers decided to outsource the task to ChatGPT, an AI chatbot, with impressive results.

title: Lots of Russian soldiers want to surrender. Ukraine makes it easier with a high-tech hotline
header: The Ukrainian military’s surrender hotline, dubbed ‘I Want to Live,’ is enticing some Russian soldiers to quit the battlefield as the war drags on.

title: Op-Ed: I’ll bet you didn’t write that — a robot did
header: How to spot the difference between an AI email and a human one.

title: Google releases ChatGPT rival AI ‘Bard’ to early testers
header: Alphabet’s Google has released its ChatGPT competitor Bard to early testers. The company says it will be ready for the public in the coming weeks.

title: The battle between Hollywood and its writers has always been ugly. It’s going to get worse
header: Battles over streaming residuals, minimum staffing and AI spell a long conflict ahead after years of simmering anger.

title: Is AI the future of Hollywood? How the hype squares with reality
header: At SXSW, the annual summit of tech boosters, all eyes turned to A.I. — and, in particular, what the emerging sector means for entertainment.

title: Before the laptop came the mainframe. But did computers generate significant new art?
header: A new LACMA show takes on art in the computer age, the Tony Award nominations, and an influential artist L.A. collective grapples with copyright disputes in this week’s newsletter.

title: 8 tips for parents and teens on social media use, from the U.S. surgeon general
header: Dr. Vivek Murthy, the U.S. surgeon general, has warned about social media’s effect on the mental health of children and adolescents. He offers guidelines for parents.

title: ‘Protect kids now.’ Social media may not be safe for young people, surgeon general warns
header: The U.S. surgeon general says there isn’t enough evidence to show that social media is safe for young people. He called on tech companies and caregivers ‘to protect kids now.’

title: Large Enterprise CIOs Expect to Grow Their IT Team to Meet Critical Demands in 2023
header: Eighty-one percent of large enterprise (LE) CIOs plan to increase their IT headcount in 2023, according to a recent survey by Gartner, Inc.
